                      Open and closed sets in Rn

                      Ex 3.8

                      Prove that open n-balls and n-dimensional open invervals are open sets in Rn.

                      Proof

                      Let B(x;r) be an open n-ball, choose any y∈B(x;r), we have d:=∥x−y∥<r, let r′=min(d,r−d), then B(y;r′)⊆B(x;r), thus y is an interior point of B(x;r), and B(x;r) is open. For any n-dimensional open interval (x1,y1)×⋯×(xn,yn), given any point p=(p1,…,pn) we have xi<pi<yi for i=1,…,n. Define

                      di=min(pi−xi,yi−pi),i=1,…,nr=min1≤i≤ndin

                      then the ball B(p;r) lies in the open interval (x1,y1)×⋯×(xn,yn), thus the open interval is open in Rn.

                      Ex 3.9

                      Prove that the interior of a set in Rn is open in Rn.

                      Proof

                      Let S be a set in Rn, and let S0 be the interior of S. For any x∈S0, x is an interior point of S, thus there is B(x,r)⊆S, this means any point y∈B(x,r/2), the ball B(y,r/2) lies in S, thus y∈S0 and so x is an interior point of S0, which means S0 is open.

                      Ex 3.10

                      If S⊆Rn, prove that int S is the union of all open subsets of Rn which are contained in S. This is described by saying that int S is the largest open subset of S.

                      Proof

                      Apparently int S is an open subset contained in S. To prove the converse, for any point which belongs to the union of all open subsets of Rn containted in S, it must belong to at least one open subset of S, thus it is an interior point of S, and belongs to int S.

                      Ex 3.11

                      If S and T are subsets of Rn, prove that

                      (int S)∩(int T)=int (S∩T)and(int S)∪(int T)⊆int (S∪T)

                      Proof

                      To prove the first conclusion, if x∈(int S)∩(int T), then x is an interior point of S and T, thus we can find B(x,r)⊆S and B(x,r′)⊆T, let R=min{r,r′}, we have B(x,R)⊆S∩T. Conversely, if x⊆S∩T, we find B(x,r)⊆S∩T, this means x is both an interior point of S and an interior point of T. To prove the second conclusion, let x∈(int S)∪(int T), then x is either an interior point of S, or an interior point of T, we can find some ball centered in x, and is either totally in S, or totally in T, thus always totally in S∪T, and the conclusion follows.

                      Ex 3.12

                      Let S′ denote the derived set and S― the closure of a set S in Rn. Prove that: a) S′ is closed in Rn; that is, (S′)′⊆S′. b) If S⊆T, then S′⊆T′. c) (S∪T)′=S′∪T′. d) (S―)′=S′ e) S― is closed in Rn. f) S― is the intersection of all closed subsets of Rn containing S. That is, S― is the smallest closed set containing S.

                      Proof

                      a) Let x∈(S′)′, then any n-ball B(x,r) contains one point y≠x,y∈S′, let R=min(|y−x|,r−|y−x|), then B(y,R)⊆B(x,r) and x∉B(y,R), and there exists one point of S distinct from y which is contained in B(y,R), thus in B(x,r), since this B(x,r) is arbitrary, we conclude x is an accumulation point of S.

                      b) If x∈S′, then for any n-ball B(x), it contains at least one point of S distinct from x, thus one point of T distinct from x, thus x∈T′.

                      c) Let x be an accumulation point of S∪T, then for each n-ball of x there is a point of S∪T distinct from x. Now if x∉S′, then there is a n-ball B such that no point in S is in, this means x∈T′, since for each n-ball contained in B shall contain a point of T.

                      d) We use S―=S∪S′, by (c) (S―)′=S′∪(S′)′, by (a) (S′)⊆S′, thus S′∪(S′)′=S′.

                      e) by (d) we know S― contains all its accumulation points, and use Theorem 3.22.

                      f) Use the fact that Rn−S― is open, any closed subset C of Rn containing S has the property that Rn−C is an open subset contained in Rn−S―, and Exercise 3.10.

                      Ex 3.13

                      Let S and T be subsets of Rn. Prove that S∩T―⊆S―∩T― and that S∩T―⊆S∩T― if S is open.

                      Proof

                      Let x∈S∩T, then for each n-ball of x there is a point of S∩T distinct from x, since this point belongs to both S and T, we have x∈S― and x∈T―. If S is open, let x∈S∩T―, we first can find a n-ball B of x such that B⊂S, for each n-ball of x contained in B, as x∈T′, will have a point of T distinct from x, this point must belongs to S since it belongs to B. thus x∈S∩T―.

                      Ex 3.14

                      A set S in Rn is called convex if, for every pair of points x and y in S and every real θ satisfying 0<θ<1, we have θx+(1−θ)y∈S. Interpret this statement geometrically (in R2 and R3) and prove that: a) Every n-ball in Rn is convex. b) Every n-dimensional open interval is convex. c) The interior of a convex set is convex. d) The closure of a convex set is convex.

                      Proof

                      a) Let B(z,r) be a n-ball, let x,y∈B(z,r) and 0<θ<1, consider

                      ∥θx+(1−θ)y−z∥=∥θ(x−z)+(1−θ)(y−z)∥≤∥θ(x−z)∥+∥(1−θ)(y−z)∥≤θr+(1−θ)r=r

                      thus θx+(1−θ)y∈B(z,r).

                      b) Let I=(a1,b1)×⋯×(an,bn) be an n-dimensional open interval. If x=(x1,…,xn) and y=(y1,…,yn) belongs to I, then we have xi∈(ai,bi) and yi∈(ai,bi) for i=1,…,n, then as long as 0<θ<1, we have xi+(1−θ)yi∈(ai,bi), thus θx+(1−θ)y∈I.

                      c) Let S be a convex set, and x,y∈int S, let z=θx+(1−θ)y for 0<θ<1, then z∈S. Since x,y∈int S, we can find B(x,r)⊂S and B(y,r)⊂S. Consider the set B(z,r), for any p∈B(z,r), we let x′=p+(x−z),y′=p+(y−z), then

                      θx′+(1−θ)y′=p+z−z=p

                      and

                      ∥x′−x∥=∥y′−y∥=∥p−z∥<r

                      thus x′∈B(x,r),y′∈B(y,r), we conclude that x′∈S,y′∈S, and p∈S since S is convex. It follows that B(z,r)⊆S and z∈int S.

                      d) Let S be a convex set, and x,y∈S―, let z=θx+(1−θ)y for 0<θ<1, we need to prove z∈S―, or z is adherent to S. Choose a n-ball of z, namely B(z,r), for this r we can find p,q∈S such that p∈B(x,r) and q∈B(y,r), define

                      z′=θp+(1−θ)q

                      then

                      ∥z−z′∥=∥θ(x−p)+(1−θ)(y−p)∥≤θ∥x−p∥+(1−θ)∥y−p∥<r

                      which means z′∈B(z,r), also z′∈S since S is convex. This shows z is adherent to S.

                      Ex 3.15

                      Let F be a collection of sets in Rn, and let S=⋃A∈FA and T=⋂A∈FA. For each of the following statements, either give a proof or exhibit a counterexample. a) If x is an accumulation point of T, then x is an accumulation point of each set A in F. b) If x is an accumulation point of S, then x is an accumulation point of at least one set A in F.

                      Proof

                      a) x is an accumulation point of T means that for each n-ball B(x,r) there is a point of T distinct from x, since this point belongs to each set A in F, we conclude that for each n-ball B(x,r) there is a point of A∈F distinct from x, thus x is an accumulation point of A for each A in F.

                      b) A counterexample is as follows: let An=(1/n,1] and F={An,n=1,2,…}, F is a collection of sets in R, we have ⋃An∈FAn=(0,1], and 0 is an accumulation point of (0,1], but each An does not have 0 as its accumulation point, since the ball (−1/2n,1/2n)∩An=∅.

                      Ex 3.16

                      Prove that the set S of rational numbers in the interval (0,1) cannot be expressed as the intersection of a countable collection of open sets.

                      Proof

                      Write S={x1,x2,…}, assume S=⋂k=1∞Sk, where each Sk is open, we construct a sequence {Qn} of closed intervals as follows: Since x1∈S1, S1 shall contain an open inverval I1 which contains x1, choose a closed interval inside I1 which has length >0 that does not include x1, name it Q1. Since Q1 contains infinitelly many rational number, we can choose one in int Q1 and name it x2 by rearranging {x2,x3,…}. Since x2∈S2, S2 shall contain an open inverval I2 which contains x2, choose a closed interval inside I2∩Q1 that does not include x2, name it Q2. The process continues as each Qi with positive length will have infinitely many rational numbers in it. We have Qn+1⊆Qn⊆Sn and xn∉Qn for each n. Now by Cantor intersection theorem, ⋂n=1∞Qn is not empty, i.e. we have some x∈⋂n=1∞Qn. Since ⋂n=1∞Qn⊆⋂n=1∞Sn=S, we have x∈S, or x=xn for some n, but this means x∉Qn, thus x∉⋂n=1∞Qn, this is a contradiction.
